The full impact of the falling pound on North East manufacturers has been laid bare after one of the region’s largest companies fell into the red despite adding more than £40m to its turnover. 
The results at automotive firm Gestamp Tallent mirror a similar picture at lawnmower manufacturer Husqvarna, both of whom are based in Newton Aycliffe , County Durham, and source many of their parts from abroad. 
Gestamp, which employs more than 2,400 people, recorded a loss of £15.8m - its first loss since 2009 - even though it had seen turnover increase £49m to £517.6m. 
Business leaders are now calling on the Government to provide more clarity surrounding Brexit negotiations as unpredictable exchange rates cause huge problems for firms operating in overseas markets. Jonathan Walker, head of policy and campaigns, North East England Chamber of Commerce (Image: Handout) 
Jonathan Walker, head of policy and campaigns at the North East England Chamber of Commerce , said: “Our recent Quarterly Economic Survey shows members concerns about exchange rates have increased significantly in recent months. 
“The weakening of the pound against the euro has made our exports more competitive but it has harmed those that import goods or components. Read More County Durham firm Husqvarna adds £43m to turnover - but sees profits fall 
“It is becoming increasingly imperative the Government provides reassurance to those trading internationally by pressing ahead with Brexit negotiations and providing clarity on future trading arrangements as soon as possible.” 
In its accounts for 2016, Gestamp said the loss was caused by “large fluctuations in the euro exchange rate” which “led to increases costs from revaluation of loans”. In total Gestamp’s operating costs rose by £78.9m.

The two firms are not the only businesses in the region to be affected by increased material costs and the weak value of the pound. Ink manufacturer Multichem has also noticed the impact unfavourable exchange rates have had on its business. 
Michael Nelson, managing director at the Hexham-based firm, said: “We are finding exchange rates, due to the Brexit situation, are affecting our business at present. Our raw materials are imported and there can be price differentiations with the exchange rates changing. 
“On the other hand, some of our customers watch these rates and ask for a price improvement if they see we are benefiting from any fluctuation. 
“There are however, businesses who do understand the situation we find ourselves in at present and are working with us to achieve both price and cash flow stability.” Like us on Facebook
